values:
Our dearest Melanie's ashes have been scattered on Langs Beach 



We'll miss you Melanie.

On Saturday March 21st @ 10 AM Melanie's parents will be holding a memorial service for Melanie at Our Lady of Peace Church, 111 South Street, New Providence, New Jersey.

Anyone who would like to make a monetary donation in Melanie's memory can donate to the art scholarship fund created in her name at
New Providence High School
35 Pioneer Drive, New Providence, NJ 07974
or
The Childhood Leukemia Foundation                                                  
870 Mantoloking Road, Suite 202, Brick, NJ 08723

Also, if you can, please give the gift of life by becoming a blood donor or bone marrow donor.

Those of us that were fortunate to have known and loved her will carry her beauty, her kindness, her strength, and her unconquerable spirit with us always. It is hard to express in words the lives she touched and the happiness she brought to everyone who knew her. Melanie was the most beautiful shining light and will be forever with us. Thank you for all of your love and thoughtfulness.

After 62 days in the hospital I finally got to go home. Well actually, I already am home. I've spent three nights sleeping in our new house, and with the aid of sleeping pills I manage some decent sleep. It's so good to be home! Although I can spend the majority of my time at my own whim now, I do still need to check in with the hospital every other day for blood tests and whathaveyou. My immune system is at it's lowest once again from my last chemo regime, but the difference this time is I don't have any infections. If I can stay away from infections for the next few weeks, then I can have the rest of the time before my bone marrow biopsy to myself and family. Which is great, since my mom is here!! She just arrived a few days ago. It's so great to have her around, and along with my sister being here it just feels amazing. And then Brian's mom gets here in a week as well! Lots to plan and look forward to to keep spirits up and getting back in shape. I lost 6k (13lb) and a lot of muscle while in the hospital, so now is my time to work on getting fitter and healthier. Thank you for your continued support, and keep me in your thoughts while the chemo does it's job these next 2 weeks.

Hi everyone, I have been updating my personal blog, but not this one for some time, and although most of you have heard through family or other ways, I figured I should post it on here as well. 

I have been in the Wellington Hospital since last Tuesday fighting a high fever, possibly caused by a bug or by my leukemia relapsing. I have been on antibiotics since then which do seem to be helping. I also had a bone marrow biopsy to confirm that indeed the leukemia was back and a course of chemotherapy was scheduled in preparation for a bone marrow transplant to come in a few months, once a donor and everything is secure. 

Right now I am on my 10th day in hospital (a record stay me!) but luckily I have been able to leave for some wheelchair accesorized walks around the hospital with Brian and Linda and then also I have had to few hours of trips home during the afternoon between chemo. So I have seen a bit of air in between these past 10 days.

I don't know much of the status of this all, communication with me has been low, but the goal is to get me back in remission through this week of high dose chemo, and then keep me in remission until I get the transplant. There are scary statistics that I try not to look at surrounding these things, so I am just hoping for the best and doing what I need to do.

Family and people far off, will be happy to know that I have a large support network here including my sister, Linda here for a year with her Kiwi partner, and a good friend from Philadelphia also here for a year, helping to support Brian and I. This doesn't include all the other friends popping out of the woodwork to help with meals and visits and even just hellos. I am feeling really supported and loved, and that's important at this stage for me, so I don't want you guys at home to worry. Just keep sending your healing thoughts, hugs & kisses and positive vibes my way, and I'll get them.  

I love you all, and will update this again as soon as I have anymore information. For now I am in hospital receiving chemo for about 4 more days. Brian seems to be doing well. He's been working away at packing up our house, since we're due to move next week, and tucking his head in to work as normally. Of course he is great at helping me and I'd be lost without him. He could definitely use some directed energies and vibes too I think :)

Last week was a busy one, and this week starts off the same. We had a launch party, 2 elections that I got to vote in, a smattering of dinners and lunches, a brainstorming morning, successful shopping and a lot more that feels like it happened months ago. It's amazing how time starts to speed up. We're now beginning to plan what to do for the holidays. New Zealand pretty much shuts down in January and everyone is expected to relax and enjoy the nice weather. We're thinking a trip to the Coromandel for some camping and site seeing, since the last time we were there with my mom it rained the whole time. We are also very tempted to get out of NZ and check out Aussie or Raro. But we might save that for later next year. We need to sell some DVDs first!

Last night was the launch party for Go New Zealand: The Immigration and Settlement DVD that Brian and I have been working on for the past year. It was great to see everyone and celebrate our huge accomplishment! I never remember how much I've let on about it on here, but we have spent the last year traveling, filming, interviewing, editing & producing this DVD. It started out as a side project and turned into something so much bigger than we ever could have expected, with lots of people involved. Go New Zealand is a 2 disc DVD set that provides all the information you need in making the decision if moving to New Zealand is right for you. We made this DVD because it's something we were looking for when we were deciding to move to New Zealand, but didn't exist. We have information about New Zealand, visas, education, healthcare, employment & more, and interviews with immigrants and New Zealand experts talking on all these subjects. If you ever wondered why we moved here, just watch the DVD and find out! We're retailing the DVD internationally through our website www.nzimmigrationdvd.com and will be selling it wholesale in and out of New Zealand as well. We are really proud of what we have accomplished and hope you will help us make it a big success by spreading the word about it. Here's a preview video of the DVD:

Yesterday was Halloween in New Zealand, and although it is not a big holiday here, Linda & I had our own celebration at our place. We spent the day cooking & baking & decorating and had all our American friends over (not planned but somehow just worked out!) We ate ghost cupcakes and orange hummus, played guitar hero and watched some classic horror flicks. It was a lot of fun! I miss big American holidays. Next up: Thanksgiving.

Besides Linda arriving, what has been keeping Brian and I so busy lately has been this DVD project we are working on. I don't know how much I've talked about it on here, but Brian and I are producing a DVD on immigration and settlement in New Zealand. We've done all the filming, editing, producing, website, EVERYTHING for it, and it has become a BIG project. You can find out more about it on our website www.nzimmigrationdvd.com you can even buy one from there! :) We are very proud of what we have done so far, and I'm looking forward to showing off all our hard work within the next 2 weeks. Let us know what you think!

Things have been crazy busy over here! Linda arrived last Friday, and brought the sun with her. It was beautiful all last week and we managed to do some outdoor activities like kite flying and a walk around the Botanic Gardens. We're off to volleyball this afternoon and yoga tomorrow. It helps that I've been feeling much better since my medication has changed. Once we are done with this DVD project there will be much more time for exploring!

Sept 21 (yesterday here in NZ) was International Peace Day. I went to the Global Mala hosted in Wellington and did 108 Om's and although there was no way could do 108 sun salutations I was able to get out around 50 which was WAY more then I was expecting. After the first round of 27 I felt really really flexible and comfortable in my body. It was a great event, everyone should do next year!

September 13 was our 5 year anniversary. Different than our wedding anniversary which is 12 August (so close!) Unfortunately we didn't do much since Brian has been sick for the past week. We did go see this house as a potential new place to live once Linda gets here. We were offered it the next day. Absolutely amazing, but timing/cost/size wasn't in our favor. But the owners were so nice! And I could have a huge garden! And it had central heating! Anyways, we're still on the look out. Besides Brian doing lots of coughing and sneezing, I've been going to yoga, cooking lots and cleaning out in hope of making room for new fashions. I'm also getting my hair cut today. yays! That's about all I can think of :)

It's interesting how your taste buds change overtime. I used to hate spinach, while the rest of my family loves it. As a kid I used to detest seeing the green globby mess plopped on a plate. Now I can't eat enough of the stuff in salads, spinach lasagna, quiches, and so forth. I also hated the taste of seaweed, so I could never eat sushi. Now I love it! Making vege sushi at home is easy, healthy and fun. And it's so pretty! I'm also obsessed with wasabi, which was weird to discover since I'm normally am not a fan of spicy things. Wasabi is different in that it's a bright huge flame at first and then goes out really quickly. None of this lingering and compiling spice that I can't handle. I think retrying foods you used to not like, could result in a new favorite food. I encourage everyone to try! (In other cooking news I've been trying to make the perfect pumpkin scone, 2 attempts in and I'm still not satisfied. I've also found a great recipe for vegan chocolate cake, which calls for almond milk. I don't think it's tasty enough to warrant it's $6.70 price tag, so will try the recipe again without it.)

I am loving having more time to do fun projects lately. Over the weekend Brian and I drove up to Levin and spent some time at a pet quarantine facility filming for the DVD project. The husband and wife that own the place are so friendly and live a life very similar to what Brian and I imagine for ourselves, amongst animals and the outdoors. It was lovely standing in the sun by the sheep run, looking out over acres of green talking about life. On the way back we stopped at the trash palace in Porirua where I got a bunch of pots and cups for only $5! I'm trying to get a bunch of potting containers together to plant a deck garden. I don't want to buy anything new or plastic so this was perfect. Now with some purchased seeds and seedlings I have the beginnings of our garden! I am also reading this great book, The Urban Homestead, that is making me super excited about producing and not just consuming!

Just got back from a video conference at the American Embassy. First time there! We listened to a 20 year old American entrepreneur, Ben Casnocha talk about his experience thus far in the business world. Very interesting, especially as an American in New Zealand to see both sidesfrom the inside. Enjoyable. Then I got home and there was a package waiting for me from my mom! It included my new glasses. So excited I made Brian take a picture!

Here's two pictures I took last weekend down on Oriental Bay Beach. It never snows in Wellington (the Rimutaka Ranges are 45 minutes outside Wellington) and sometimes I miss it. But only in it's beautiful pristine form, not the "get to work through blackened wet slush" form. We are planning a Ruapehu ski/sledding trip in the next few weeks, so that should satisfy my yearly desire to touch snow :)

Our friends from Philadelphia, Saxon & Ian, live in Auckland and have a blog. Saxon has a great sense of humor and talks about her experiences as an American in NZ, their travels and their cats. It's awesome. And makes me feel like this blog is inadequate. It made me want to post and talk about all the non exciting things we have been doing lately. But, I guess there have been some exciting things. We are making great headway on the DVD project. All components have been touched, and some are nearly done (filming, editing, website, DVD packaging- not done, but touched :) We've got lots of interviews and filming scheduled for this week and next, including 2 government departments, one university and a few immigrants. We bought a new scooter. It's brand new. Cost more than we wanted to spend. But it's pretty. And awesome. My hair is growing, and I even get compliments on it from strangers. I'll get Brian to take a picture any day now... 6 weeks till my sister arrives in Wellington! I went to wine tasting with the American Womens Network over the weekend. I enjoyed just the right amount of delicious New Zealand wine and learned a bunch to boot. A highlight was the dessert wine infused with "Christmas cake spices." It's been raining for the past few days, which has been a great excuse to stay inside and read, listen to audio books and cuddle with the cat. I am currently enjoying an autobiography by a recently introduced friend Getrude Matshe and Dr Andrew Weil's "Meditation for Optimum Health." I have also been enjoying cooking lately, including pumpkin scones (might need to retry this), chickpea burgers, my own juice combos with a borrowed juicer from a friend and fresh fruits, and a collaboration between Brian and I produced a delicious vegetarian chili last night. Still a long list of new recipes left to try. I'm all about recipes with "Christmas cake spices." Well I'm sure there is more I can ramble on about, but you are probably bored by now, and I will save somethings for next time. Miss you all. xoxo
Found posted up around Wellington: And yes, mine has been sent!

So here are the rest of my photos. I am ready to move on from recapping this trip and get back to all the tasks at hand, so enjoy these!! At the South street Seaport, failed attempts to see 2 separate exhibits. Lounging, games and food instead! Linda's apartment in Queens. With Nick on the subway, after lots and lots of Indian food! Big vs. Little Bowling, a family tradition. What The Bean looks like now after sufficient fattening. TV's at the Petrol pumps! Early morning crabbing trip down the Jersey shore. All hail 32 ounce 87 cent sodas & 1.70 hot dog combos while shopping! Because a friend didn't believe they actually existed.

So we are finally dwindling down on the pictures I have left from our time in the US. Here are some from my parents place in New Jersey: My Aunt brought over bagels, just the way I remember them! My parents live in a beautiful suburban area with lots of wildlife. My mom would say, oh look there's one of the woodpeckers, or quick the family of deer is crossing the lawn! We also visited the Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge where we used to go for walks and bike rides when I was a kid. We saw lots more there too.

After looking at beautiful food presentations online I had to post my own. Well not my own personal concoctions, but some of the beautiful tastiness I had while in NYC. Linda took us to this amazing French Cafe where they serve the best french toast you will ever eat. I was also excited to go to Alice's Tea Cup, with Lauren, who came all the way from Boston to meet me. We enjoyed this delicious tower of assorted scones, sandwiches, cakes & cookies, along with 2 pots of tea. I don't know how, but after all that food we walked (very leisurely) nearly 50 blocks back to Penn Station; past Central Park where thousands were queuing for a Bon Jovi concert that night & then Times Square. OMG people.

While in NY I stayed with Linda overnight while she was dog sitting for a coworker. Sophie and Rocky renewed my faith in small dogs. After being around dogs for a good part of our trip, Brian and I are now seriously considering adopting one. We wouldn't be able to keep one where we live now, but I plan to have some space in the next place me move to...

I have safely arrived in New Zealand after many transfers and much traveling. I have an acupuncture appointment in half an hour to help with jetlag and a big stack of work to deal with when I get back. For you, here are some photos:

While in Philadelphia Justin, Brian's brother, took us on a trip to his secret climbing spot in the Poconos. It was a perfect spot to be on a perfect day. Deep water soloing. What I was doing while that was going on :) I also took these too. All the free organic blueberries you could eat! But when that doesn't satisfy try a plate of grease and a cold A&W.

Here are some photos from our trip, starting with our time in Philadelphia. Kelly, thank you so much for taking off work to spend time with us! Chaz, thank you so much for coming up from Florida to see us! Mac, the Radke's dog, enjoying his first time in the city. Spending time with him put the idea of having a dog in our heads. Eric, doing his DJ thing. Cheesesteak heaven. WE MISS YOU ALL ALREADY!

Today is another day of shopping (I can not believe I haven't gotten sick of this yet) and then off to NYC to spend the weekend with Linda. She has a volleyball tournament in Coney Island on Saturday, so I will spending the day with my friend Lauren. I met Lauren in NZ, but she is originally from the US. She's meeting me in the city so we can catch up on the last year + that we haven't seen each other. So excited! Dinner at an organic Vege Restaurant with Linda. The Sangria was awesome! A view of one of the waterfall installations under the Brooklyn Bridge. Greek dinner in Queens. A bad photo taken on our drive back to Jersey from NYC. It was taken at about 1am, and illustrates the amount of light pollution coming from Jersey City. I will try and take some more photos this weekend, but I don't expect the city to look any less grey...

One of the great things about being back is talking with people we haven't heard from in a long time. I was so happy to hear people tell me they read this blog and enjoy it. It's great that we can share with you what we have been up to, but you should all do the same! Hardly any of you comment! Please do! Let us know you're reading, ask us questions, tell us what you like and don't like and fill us in on what you have been doing. I know some may not feel comfortable with other people reading what they have written, so from now on I will screen all comments. That means we can read them, but no one else can- that way you have no excuse! With love,

Breakfast for 1 from iHop. A hike up to Manoa Falls. Me trying on hats on one of our shopping excursions (stores were open to 11pm everyday and there were soooo many of them). See a purchased example in the next photo. Obviously surfing is huge in Hawaii, and we saw lots of these cool surfboard attachments on bikes. Brian and his mom also went surfing. I don't have many photos of it because I used that time to either be swimming in the bathtub warm water or resting on the beach. This is the beach in Waikiki. We also went snorkeling, which was absolutely amazing. I don't like having my head under water, but after eventually getting over that we saw incredible tropical fish & coral, a crab, a blowfish and got to swim within arms length of a sea turtle for a while. Favorite part of the trip!

We've been back on the east coast for about a week now and having fun running around, but here is a recap from our time in Hawaii. Pictures will be broken into 2 posts. The view from the deck off our hotel room. The hotel lobby at night. We had dinner at Nobu, the hotel's restaurant, one night. Tasty Japanese: lobster salad, miso encrusted cod, heart of palm tempura and more! The weather for the week we were in Honolulu (on Ilene's iPhone). My favorite Hawaiian drink, a Lava Flow: Pina Colada infused with Strawberry Daiquiri. Views from our drive around O'ahu. And I thought Crocs were only popular in New Zealand! More to come!

I thought that while traveling in the US I would take pictures of some of the awesome food we have been eating. Some things that we really miss and can't get in New Zealand, and just some amazingly huge American meals. Here's the first of the series. A toasted fruit dessert in Hawaii, featuring an old friend from Philadelphia Cindy. No illusion here, it was as huge as it looks!

So far our trip has been great. We have done a lot already and seen many family and friends we have missed for a long time. We even ran into a friend that flew into Philly to see us without planning it! We have lucked out with weather and timing and I have nothing to complain about :) Photos are on their way!

We leave tomorrow morning on a 7am flight headed to Hawaii. The weather in Wellington has been cold and gusty so it seems to be perfect timing. There are still some things to be done before our departure, but overall I feel we are in a good place and we both are really starting to get excited! Extending our trip is looking doubtful after several attempts already, but I am holding out hope. We already have plans for a few days of the trip which should be lots of fun. Yesterday I booked a 6:30am yoga class then breakfast and massage at a spa in Waikiki. It's not the yoga retreat I'd like to go on, but it's close and should be pretty inspiring (but I forgot how expensive the US can be-and tax isn't included in the quoted price! How quickly I forget!) Not sure how often we'll be able to get online while traveling, but I will post updates and pictures of our trip as soon as I can.

Can't wait to see you all soon!

It is now only 13 days till we leave for the homeland!! I figure I should post our itinerary as it stands now since people keep asking. There will be a lot of moving around, so hopefully we can connect during this time. 

19 June: Morning, Brian & Melanie leave Wellington head to Honolulu, Hawaii
19- 23 June: Brian & Melanie & Eileen in Hawaii
23 June: Afternoon, Brian & Melanie fly to Los Angeles California & spend the night
24 June: Afternoon, Melanie flys to New Jersey, Brian flys to Philadelphia
24 June- 28 June: Melanie in NJ, Brian in Philadelphia
28 June- 3 July: Melanie & Brian in Philadelphia
3 July- 6 July: Melanie & Brian in NJ
6 July- 8 July- Melanie in NJ, Brian in Philadelphia

As of now we are set to fly out on 8 July, but we are most likely going to push this back one week, but nothing is set yet. Soooo there might be an extra week after the 8th that we are around. 

I will keep updating this schedule as things change. We are very excited!!! and in the process of getting everything sorted before we leave. See you all soon!

From the 15th-19th of May, Brian and I were up in Auckland filming for our DVD project. We had perfect weather and got most of the shots we were planning on getting quickly so we had lots of down time for fun stuff. Sunset from Mount Eden. The Sky Tower at night. Marina with the Harbour Bridge in the background. Enjoying the view at the marina. Sailboat in Devonport. View from North Head in Devonport. Auckland city across the harbour. Brian protecting the city from Devonport. View of Rangitoto from Mount Victoria. A friend of Brians. Botanic Gardens. The beach at Mission Bay.

With all my stomach issues, this week hasn't been too eventful (I didn't even leave the house for a second on Thursday) but Nachos! Rollerskating with American friends in Upper Hutt. Enjoying outdoor music & beautiful weather outside Homegrown. More food with more American friends! A trip out to Paekakariki for friends, delicious South African dinner & cute puppies! Kelly & Rani expand their family. Kelly is 10 months pregnant, and got another puppy! of some things we did last week! Brian's new camera arrived so I finally have some recent photos with me in them!

Here in NZ it is just a few hours away from the month of May. I can not believe how fast time flies. Although sometimes during my treatment time seemed to stand still, looking back I can't believe it has been nearly a year since I was diagnosed with Leukemia. I can not believe it. Me. Melanie. Getting through treatment for cancer at 25. Remembering that I celebrated that quarter of a century mark in the ER getting a blood transfusion. But I am putting that all behind me.

It has been a few weeks since the main part of my treatment ended. My Hickman line is out, I've played some volleyball and gone to some yoga classes, but it's far from all over. I spent hours on Monday night vomiting and had another visit to the ER. I've spent the last week or so feeling nauseous and utterly drained. This is harder than I thought! The other stuff was expected to be hard. This, the end bit was supposed to be easy! Back to normal as the doctors said. But taking so many pills every day (including oral chemotherapy) is not normal. Maybe I need a dosage adjustment, maybe I need time for my body to adjust, but it does take its toll. It is hard, and I am fighting.

But I know I can do this. With all your support I will get through. I am so excited to come home and see all of you that I love so much. I am so excited that I (think I have) convinced Brian that we need to stay longer then we originally planned. Hopefully I can spend extra time giving you all hugs!

Lots of stuff has been happening but I haven't known what to write about. The ending of my treatment was sort of anticlimactic once I realised that I would still be in and out of the hospital at least 2 times a week for blood tests, checkups and lumbar punctures. I know it will become less frequent, but right now things don't seem too much different. I am taking up to 15 pills a day and feeling really tired. BUT I do feel a lot healthier and happier and have been getting out and about :) Last weekend we drove up to Taupo for a long weekend of filming for DVD project which turned into early nights and mornings and enjoyment of beautiful weather. Brightest rainbow ever! You could see the whole thing end to end- I have a video of it I will try and post soon. Lake Taupo as we came in Friday night. Bungy jumping over a beautiful river. Huka falls. During our walk at Craters of the Moon- an active geothermal area in Taupo Sunrise from our hostels balcony. Besides that I am counting down till our visit to the US (less than 2 months now!) And trying to focus on organising and making progress on all our projects. How time just flies!

I'm very grateful that my cancer has an end. I'm very aware that many people aren't as lucky as I am. They make the best of years in treatment, or are worried by thoughts of reoccurrence for years afterwards. Although there is always a chance that my cancer will come back (a high 50% chance if I believed in statistics) I do believe that this is it for me. I believe I am cured, I have cheated death as someone said today. 

I have learned many lessons that have changed my life. I have grown closer to my family, to Brian and his family. I have made new, lifelong friends. I have felt the touch of so many people on my life and I am forever indebted to them for it. I believe I am a better person because of it. I'm grateful for this experience because of all that it has brought me. Don't get me wrong it has been a hard hard journey, that isn't over yet. But I can see the good in it. And I believe it happened for a reason. 

But I am glad that it is nearly over. 2 more days. I try to stay in the present, but can't help but think about the future. And it looks really bright.

We finally have official plans for coming back to the US! We booked our NZ-US plane tickets yesterday and now are much poorer, but very excited! It will have been over 2 and half years since we arrived in New Zealand by the time we come back to visit. 

Brian and I will be spending a few days in Hawaii before we make our way to the east coast, but will probably arrive around June 24 and leave around July 7 (I still have to book our LA-PHL flights.) This time will be split between PA and NJ, not totally sure on exact dates yet, but it would be lovely to see everyone! We're thinking of having a 4th of July party in NJ and then a going away party in PA that weekend before we leave. So excited to see everyone- hope you'll be around!

I've been using it for a while, but just got the brilliant idea now to ask who else is on it, so I can add you to my contacts. Especially if you're outside of NZ! You can search for me under my name. And if you don't have a Skypeaccount, you should get one! It's free to talk through it which means you can talk to me as much as you want even across oceans :)

all our traveling updates, I figure I should give a cancer update too.

I only have about about 1-2 months of treatment left! That includes 2 weeks recovering inbetween chemotherapy and some time after my last treatment to recover and have my Hickman line removed. I am very excited I am so close to the end. By then it will have been nearly a year (around 10 months) that I have been going through this. Once my intensive treatment is over I will still have about 18 months of "maintenance" treatment which involves hospital visits, chemo injections, blood tests & medication. BUT it doesn't sound bad at all after what I have already been through. 

As you probably already know I have been in remission since my second month of treatment, but leukemia comes back easily and so everything I have done since then has been to prevent that from happening. There is of course still the chance that it will come back, but I will worry about that if and when that happens. In the meantime I am looking forward to being able to swim and take baths again, travel and visit all our friends and family in the US (planning for June 2008!) and getting back into volleyball, horse riding and just enjoying an active life again. 

Thank you for all your support to this point, it has been an amazing help in my mental & physical recovery and I am grateful every day to have such supportive family and friends.

xoxo

Day 2 we did some more shooting in Christchurch, and went back up the Port Hills for some clearer shots. Then we left Christchurch and headed on our way to Greymouth on the west coast. We drove through Arthur's Pass which was absolutely beautiful and we could only imagine how much more amazing it must be in the winter when all the mountains are capped in snow. We stayed at a cute backpackers in Greymouth that night, which was the extent of our visit to the west coast. Day 3 was mostly spent driving through Lewis Pass. We stopped for a quick tramp to see some waterfalls and then took another stop in Kaikoura (famous for it's marine life, although we didn't see any whales or dolphins, we did see seals!) We ended up driving north to Blenheim which took us through wine country and more amazing views. We stayed in a gross backpackers in Blenheim that night, quickly left town the next morning and drove to Nelson. We were pretty disappointed with Nelson after hearing lots of people rave about it, and with the weather catching up to us again we did a quick tour and then made our way back to Picton. On the way we came across this amazing spot below a bridge. The water was crystal clear and people were jumping off rocks, swimming, sunbathing- it was beautiful. I would have been in that water in a second if I could have (I'm not allowed to be submerged in water due to my Hickman line :( In Picton we had a nice dinner at the same seafood restaurant we went to the last time we were there and then hopped on the 7pm ferry. The weather was horrible and the ferry was delayed, we didn't get home till 11pm. Thankfully we had taken some great anti-nausea medication or we would definitely have been sick on the boat. Overall it was a great whirlwind trip. We covered a lot of ground, and even though it might not have been as relaxing as I would have liked, we accomplished most of what we went down there for. I was really impressed with Christchurch, and look forward to spending more time there, and checking out some of the other spots that we missed.

This past weekend Brian and I took a trip to the south island to do some shooting for our NZ Immigration DVD. Below you can see a picture of the driving route we took. Because I have so many pictures I want to show you, I'm going to break this post up into 2. Day 1: We flew into Christchurch early Friday morning and had a sunny, hot day of wandering around and filming in the city. We loved Christchurch! It was much bigger than we thought, and we were happy to see lots of old character buildings that reminded us of Philadelphia. We also drove out to Lyttleton Harbour, then Sumners Beach. On our way back into Christchurch we drove through the Port Hills, but by then it was getting really windy, cool and rainy. We were exhausted by the time we got back, so after dinner we crashed at our hotel for the night. Christchurch Cathedral in Cathedral Square. Bridge crossing the Avon River that flows through Christchurch. Kinetic sculptures outside the art gallery. Part of a sculpture designed by Richard Taylor of Weta workshop for the outdoor Dyslexia Discovery Exhibit. A really neat cave you could walk around in at Sumners beach. A sequoia in the middle of Christchurch's Botanic Gardens. And the rest are pictures from the Botanic Gardens, taken with mom in mind :) Rose garden. I was sad that my new camera didn't arrive before we left (and still hasn't arrived!) but my point and shoot still did the job. We also took tons of footage with the video camera and I'm hoping to get some of the clips up on here eventually :) See my next post for the rest of our trip.

On Friday I couldn't sit still so I went on a cleaning spree on our new place. I weeded, swept, picked up trash, vacuumed and of course took some pictures so you can see where we live. Here's the outside of the place with our car in front of the garage. This is the view from the deck above the garage looking out into town. This is the view looking off the other side of the deck. We can see the ocean! (even if it is only a tiny square :) The view from the deck looking down on the road. What you see out our back bedroom window into our backyard.

One of the best things about IFIX is all the people we get to meet. Yesterday we spent the afternoon/evening in Plimmerton at a customers "retreat." He lives in an amazing house set on 5 acres of bush with little tracks winding through gardens, olive trees and grape vines. He has quails that run into his office and Tui's that drink out of cups. It was an amazing day and I can't wait to go back. Taffy takes amazing photos on his property and abroad, and just had a book printed about Tommy the Tui. We'll be using some his photos on our DVD and website.

I just realised I never posted about this on missingthebean, so sorry to anyone who has already read it over my on other journal. On Jan 5 Brian and I went out to sea with our friend Oliver and 12 other people to go fishing for Kingfish (apparently according to Wikipedia aka yellowtail amberjack.) I was a little weary about going for 3 reasons. one. My legs were still not fully functional and I was unsure if I could maneuver around the boat. two. The last time I was out deep sea fishing was eight or nine years ago and I spent the whole time curled up in a ball feeling like death. three. Kingfish are HUGE. The smaller ones weighing 50-60 pounds! I was also a little disheartened (who's kidding, a lot disheartened) when our captain was giving us some information before we set off and amongst other things said that Kingfish are near impossible to reel in, and that we were going out to rough seas and if you got seasick easily you should step off the boat immediately. Hrmmmm. I decided to have a go anyways. And it worked out. I had gotten some prescription seasickness pills beforehand and they worked like a charm (or I just don't get seasick anymore, but we'll never know) I wasn't able to walk around the boat much, but there were plenty of railings for me to hold onto so standing was no problem. I was scared to try fishing at first because of how much the boat was rocking (I didn't want to fall over the edge!) but I found a way I could still hold on and fish at the same time. AND I caught 3 Kahawai. They weren't as big as Kingfish, but still the biggest fish I ever caught at between 1-2 feet long. There wasn't that many fish caught (by the 14 males on board), so I was pretty excited to have caught 3. I also saw a shark and a barracuda. All the meat was divided up amongst who wanted it once we got back, and I used our portion to make a Kahawai (tastes like Snapper) coconut curry. It was tasty. This was the only guy that caught a Kingfish, and he caught 2! (that's one of them BTW) This is how I had to fish, with one hand holding on for dear life.
